body_text: 7. okt. 2025 Af Nanna Sofie Pehrson P3-vÃ¦rt Helin Erdem debuterer pÃ¥ scenen i â€˜GRWMâ€™ â€“ og udleverer mediebranchen og sig selv Hvis du frygter at blive kaldt ud foran en fyldt sal, skal du sÃ¦tte dig pÃ¥ bagerste rÃ¦kke til â€™GRWMâ€™ pÃ¥ Aveny-T. Helin Erdem er ude med riven. TEATER. P3â€™s (efter eget udsagn) Â»medium kendteÂ« vÃ¦rts-darling Helin Erdem skifter for en stund skÃ¦rmen ud med de skrÃ¥ brÃ¦dder. Hun er kendt for at bruge sin platform og skarpe humor til at sÃ¦tte fokus pÃ¥ tabubelagte emner som reprÃ¦sentation, privilegier og eurocentriske skÃ¸nhedsidealer, ofte med udgangspunkt i sit eget liv som minoritetsetnisk kvinde. Og til trods for at hun pÃ¥ Aveny-T prÃ¦senterer sig som en nar pÃ¥ scenen, er der ingen tvivl om, at hun har en aktivistisk agenda. Sponsoreret indhold Men da forestillingen er ovre, kan jeg ikke lade vÃ¦re med at tÃ¦nke: Â»Er det her det rette format?Â« I forestillingen â€˜GRWMâ€™ (kort for get ready with me) forsÃ¸ger Erdem og instruktÃ¸r Sofie Diemer at vise konsekvenserne af at kapitalisere pÃ¥ sin identitet. Udgangspunktet er hendes egne oplevelser som dansker med kurdiske rÃ¸dder i mediebranchen, som hun i sin tid blev en del af via DRâ€™s Talenthold. Det munder ud i en monolog om forlommer og baglommer, og hvordan Kultur- og Mediedanmark i Ã¥rtier har tjent penge pÃ¥ minoriteters lidelseshistorier. Historier, der helst skal vÃ¦re voldsomme nok til, at hvide majoritetsdanskere finder dem fascinerende, men helst ikke sÃ¥ voldsomme, at det bliver ubehageligt. Som Erdem siger i monologen: Â»De vil ikke udfordres. I vil underholdesÂ«. HvornÃ¥r er nok, nok? Jeg rystede lidt i bukserne pÃ¥ Helin Erdems vegne, da jeg fandt ud af, at hendes scenedebut var en monolog. Der er ingen til at stÃ¸tte dig, nÃ¥r du vakler, eller give et boost, nÃ¥r energien falder. Men der hersker ingen tvivl om, at hun er en performer. Sponsoreret indhold Med et fotografi af sig selv som bagtÃ¦ppe trÃ¦der hun ind i scenerummet klÃ¦dt som en nar i sort, hvidt, grÃ¸nt og rÃ¸dt. Med ansigtet malet hvidt og et forvrÃ¦nget joker-smil tvinger hun os allesammen til at fÃ¸lge hende pÃ¥ Instagram. SÃ¥ er forestillingen i gang. Det stÃ¥r hurtigt klart, at publikum er hendes vigtigste medspiller. Vi er fÃ¸lgere, journalister og de nepo-babyer, hun er oppe imod i sin kamp for at forblive aktuel i en hastigt accelererende opmÃ¦rksomhedsÃ¸konomi. Derfor et tip til dig, der ikke er vild med at blive kaldt ud i en fyldt sal: sÃ¦t dig pÃ¥ bagerste rÃ¦kke. Ser man bort fra ubehaget ved publikumsinddragelsen er det dog fÃ¸rst i anden halvdel, at vi virkelig mÃ¦rker Erdem. Ã…rsagen syntes at vÃ¦re premierenerver og en lidt vaklende indledning, der er lÃ¦nge om at nÃ¥ frem til monologens egentlige budskab. Der er meget, hun gerne vil fortÃ¦lle os om sig selv, sin branche, om hvordan hun ser verden, og hvordan hun oplever, verden ser hende. Midt i alt dette fungerer hendes Instagram-besÃ¦ttelse som en rÃ¸d trÃ¥d: Sponsoreret indhold Â»KÃ¦re 19.000 fÃ¸lgere, get ready with me, mens jeg fortÃ¦ller omâ€¦Â«. Undervejs gÃ¥r det op for hende, at jo mere autentisk (og aktivistisk) hun er, desto fÃ¦rre fÃ¸lgere fÃ¥r hun, hvilket er katastrofalt i kultur- og mediebranchen, hvor der er en direkte linje mellem opmÃ¦rksomhed og jobsikkerhed. I et forsÃ¸g pÃ¥ at fastholde sin relevans og finde et Â»tilpas fordÃ¸jeligt politisk budskabÂ« bliver hun en anden. Men hvornÃ¥r er nok, nok? At vÃ¦re en dansende abe Erdem vil gerne fortÃ¦lle os, at hun ved, at hendes minoritetsbaggrund har vÃ¦ret en vej ind i mediebranchen, der helst vil undgÃ¥ anklager om manglende reprÃ¦sentation. Men ogsÃ¥ at de muligheder, hun er blevet givet, kommer med en pris. Hun er trÃ¦t af at vÃ¦re en dansende abe for mediebranchen, der er blevet hendes levebrÃ¸d. Hun mÃ¥ finde balancen mellem at sÃ¦lge og sÃ¦lge ud. â€˜GRWMâ€™ er en selviscenesÃ¦ttelse af den Helin Erdem, vi kender fra medierne (etablerede sÃ¥vel som sociale). Og som med sÃ¥ mange andre autofiktive vÃ¦rker er grÃ¦nsen mellem virkelighed og fiktion uklar. Sponsoreret indhold Monologen kredser generelt om temaer, som hun er kendt for at have en holdning til. Meget vil derfor fÃ¸les genkendeligt for dem, der tidligere har fulgt Erdem, inklusive de wakeupcalls, hun forsÃ¸ger at give os, nÃ¥r hun danser rundt i en gorilladragt ifÃ¸rt leopardbikini for at understrege sin afstandtagen fra medieprostitution. MÃ¥ske havde det fÃ¸ltes mere udfordrende, hvis hun var gÃ¥et hÃ¥rdere til os. For jo, vi vil gerne udfordres og ikke kun underholdes. En af de scener, der virkelig stÃ¥r ud, er, da Erdem, skrÃ¦mt og indigneret, beskriver, hvordan en DR-chef aggressivt truer med at Ã¸delÃ¦gge hendes karriere, efter hun har afslÃ¸ret hans hygge-racistiske bemÃ¦rkninger for offentligheden. Det er ikke til at vide om situationen har udspillet sig i virkeligheden eller ej. Men uanset viser den os, hvordan magt og undertrykkelse stadig er et problem i mediebranchen â€“ alene fordi historien fremstÃ¥r trovÃ¦rdig. Kort sagt:I â€˜GRWMâ€™ udleverer Helin Erdem sig selv og mediebranchen i et Ã¦rligt forsÃ¸g pÃ¥ at afdÃ¦kke den menneskelige pris, man betaler for at blive en succes. Men meget af det har vi hÃ¸rt fÃ¸r. â€˜GRWMâ€™ pÃ¥ Aveny-T. IscenesÃ¦ttelse: Sofie Diemer. Medvirkende: Helin Erdem. Tekst: Sofie Diemer og Helin Erdem. Scenografi: Mai Katsume. Spilleperiode: Til 1. november. Sponsoreret indhold

title: Ridley Scott synes, at de fleste film i dag Â»er lortÂ«
author: Benjamin Damon
body_text: 7. okt. 2025 Af Benjamin Damon Ridley Scott synes, at de fleste film i dag Â»er lortÂ« Ridley Scott i 2023. (Foto: Gareth Cattermole/Getty Images) Den fire gange Oscar-nominerede instruktÃ¸r Ridley Scott har aldrig vÃ¦ret kendt for at holde igen med de bramfri replikker. Da hans â€™Napoleonâ€™-film for et par Ã¥r siden fik lunkne anmeldelser i Frankrig, reagerede han for eksempel ved at konstatere, at Â»franskmÃ¦ndene ikke engang kan lide sig selvÂ«. Sponsoreret indhold Under et interview ved det britiske filminstitut i weekenden, som ellers var en fejring af hans imponerende karriere, kastede han sig sÃ¥ledes ogsÃ¥ ud i en stÃ¸rre nedsabling af Hollywoods nuvÃ¦rende tilstand. Det skriver Deadline. Â»MÃ¦ngden af film der laves i dag er vitterligt millioner globalt. Ikke tusinder, men millioner â€¦ og det meste af det er lortÂ«, forklarede Scott. Da han blev adspurgt om, hvorvidt han har en comfort-film, han holder af at se, svarede han mÃ¥ske ikke helt overraskende: Â»Vi drukner i middelmÃ¥dighed. SÃ¥ det jeg gÃ¸r â€“ og det er en forfÃ¦rdelig ting â€“ men jeg er begyndt at se mine egne film, og de er faktisk ret gode. Og de Ã¦ldes heller ikkeÂ«. Han fortsatte med et konkret eksempel: Â»Jeg sÃ¥ â€™Black Hawk Downâ€™ den anden aften, og tÃ¦nkte â€™hvordan fanden gjorde jeg det?â€™. Men jeg tror, at af og til kommer der en god film, og det er en lettelse, at der er nogen derude, der laver en god filmÂ«. Ridley Scott er snart aktuel med den stjernebesatte sci-fi-film â€˜The Dog Starsâ€™, som er baseret pÃ¥ Peter Hellers roman af samme navn. I centrale roller optrÃ¦der Jacob Elordi, Margaret Qualley, Josh Brolin, Guy Pearce og Benedict Wong. â€˜The Dog Starsâ€™ fÃ¥r international premiere den 27. marts 2026, men en dansk biografpremiere kendes ikke endnu. title: Taylor Swift kan ikke relatere til sit 2024-album: Â»Jeg har det ikke elendigt lÃ¦ngereÂ«
author: Morten KildebÃ¦k
body_text: 7. okt. 2025 Af Morten KildebÃ¦k Taylor Swift kan ikke relatere til sit 2024-album: Â»Jeg har det ikke elendigt lÃ¦ngereÂ« Taylor Swift. Hun var nemlig pÃ¥ det tidspunkt i sit liv et andet, mere lykkeligt sted. Derfor glÃ¦der hun sig nu over at vÃ¦re aktuel med et album, der afspejler hendes nuvÃ¦rende humÃ¸r. Og da jeg udgav den, var jeg sÃ¥ lykkeligÂ«, fortsÃ¦tter hun. Sponsoreret indhold Â»SÃ¥ det var sÃ¥dan lidt: Jeg elsker denne kunst. Jeg elsker denne smukke kunst om elendighed. Jeg har det dog ikke elendigt lÃ¦ngere, sÃ¥ det fÃ¸les mÃ¦rkeligt at tale om pladen, for det er lidt sÃ¥dan, at du kan godt vÃ¦re stolt af arbejdet, men samtidig ikke rigtig kunne relatere til den person, du var dengangÂ«. title: â€™Monster: The Ed Gein Storyâ€™: Er ny Netflix-sÃ¦son seriÃ¸st en hyldest til en seriemorder?
author: Damla ErdÃ¶lek
body_text: 7. okt. 2025 Af Damla ErdÃ¶lek â€™Monster: The Ed Gein Storyâ€™: Er ny Netflix-sÃ¦son seriÃ¸st en hyldest til en seriemorder? 'Monster: The Ed Gein Story'. (Foto: Netflix) Der er et Ã¸jeblik i â€™Monster: The Ed Gein Storyâ€™, hvor serien nÃ¦sten forvandler sig til et studie i depraveret ensomhed. Ed (Charlie Hunnam) sidder alene pÃ¥ et mÃ¸rkt vÃ¦relse i snebeklÃ¦dte Wisconsin og tÃ¦nder sin radio. Et grÃ¸nt lys flimrer i mÃ¸rket, og en kvindestemme trÃ¦nger igennem â€“ lavmÃ¦lt, med tysk accent. Stemmen tilhÃ¸rer Ilse Koch, den berygtede â€œBitch of Buchenwaldâ€, som her dukker op som en hallucination, der taler til ham gennem Ã¦teren: Â»Du er et menneske, Ed. Tillad ingen at kalde dig et monster.Â« Sponsoreret indhold Han svarer hende, med en blanding af barnlig stolthed og desperation. Det er et kort, men foruroligende smukt Ã¸jeblik. Et glimt af den psykologiske dybde, serien kunne have haft ved at portrÃ¦ttere en mand, der gÃ¥r i oplÃ¸sning mellem isolation og skyld. Men det, der kunne have vÃ¦ret et rÃ¥t studie i ensomhed og lÃ¦ngslen efter at blive elsket, bliver i stedet et kunstnerisk tableau over, hvor fascinerede vi egentlig er af mÃ¦nd som Ed Gein. Efter â€™Dahmerâ€™ og â€™The Lyle and Erik Menendez Storyâ€™ fortsÃ¦tter Ryan Murphy og Ian Brennan deres â€™Monsterâ€™-antologi med historien om Ed Gein, den virkelige morder og gravrÃ¸ver, der inspirerede â€™Psychoâ€™, â€™The Texas Chainsaw Massacreâ€™ ogâ€™The Silence of the Lambsâ€™. En mand, som bÃ¥de mytologisk og filmisk er blevet gysergenrens arv. â€™Sons of Anarchyâ€™-stjernen Charlie Hunnam spiller Ed Gein med en uventet og nÃ¦sten perverteret skrÃ¸belighed. Hans stemme er skinger, nÃ¦sten Mickey Mouse-agtig og stÃ¥r i skÃ¦rende kontrast til hans atletiske fysik, og det giver karakteren en konstant dissonans, som bÃ¥de fascinerer og vÃ¦kker ubehag. Sponsoreret indhold Han ligner prÃ¦cist det, som serien vil fremhÃ¦ve ved Ed Gein: et voksent barn, fanget i sin mors moralske spÃ¦ndetrÃ¸je. Moren, Augusta (Laurie Metcalf), er isnende puritansk, prÃ¦diker synd og straf og har en kropslig autoritet, der fÃ¸les nÃ¦rmest overnaturlig. Hver gang hun trÃ¦der ind i et rum, trÃ¦kker hun al luften ud af det. BÃ¥de som levende og dÃ¸d portrÃ¦tteres hun mesterligt, som et spÃ¸gelse, der holder Ed fanget i sit eget hjem og i sin egen krop. Seriens mest potente scener er dem, der tÃ¸r opholde sig ved mor og sÃ¸n. I et afsnit forsÃ¸ger Eds bror Henry (Hudson Oz) at konfrontere ham: Han vil vÃ¦k fra gÃ¥rden, men mest af alt vÃ¦k fra Augustas klaustrofobiske tag. SkÃ¦nderiet eskalerer, ilden tager fat i marken, og nÃ¦ste morgen ligger Henry dÃ¸d. Ed ser pÃ¥ kroppen af sin afdÃ¸de bror med en blanding af sorg og forlÃ¸sning. Scenen fortÃ¦lles i stilhed â€“ uden musik, uden effekter, og dÃ©r mÃ¦rker man igen, hvor stÃ¦rkt et portrÃ¦t det kunne have vÃ¦ret, hvis sÃ¦sonen forlod sig mere pÃ¥ sit psykologiske materiale end pÃ¥ sine meta-referencer. Sponsoreret indhold For Murphy og Brennan kan ikke lade vÃ¦re med at overÃ¸se os med deres kÃ¦rlighed til gyserhistorien og til de vÃ¦rker, Gein inspirerede. Serien genskaber â€™Psychoâ€™s brusebadsscene, â€™Texas Chainsaw Massacreâ€™s middagsscene og â€™Silence of the Lambsâ€™s kÃ¦lder i minutiÃ¸se detaljer. Det er som at se en collage af horrorhistorie, udfÃ¸rt med dygtighed, men uden retning. I teorien er gentagelserne tÃ¦nkt som selvkritik: Vi ser det, fordi vi ikke kan lade vÃ¦re. I praksis bliver serien bare snarere et Ã¦stetisk orgie, der dvÃ¦ler ved billederne, sÃ¥rene og skindene. Den fordÃ¸mmer publikums fascination, men dyrker den i samme bevÃ¦gelse. Introduktionen af krigsforbryderen Ilse Koch som hallucineret modbillede er seriens mest dristige idÃ©. Hendes stemme reprÃ¦senterer forbindelsen mellem virkelighedens rÃ¦dsel og dens mytologisering â€“ mellem dokumenteret ondskab og dens Ã¦stetiske transformation i film og fiktion. Sponsoreret indhold Hun bliver for Ed et bevis pÃ¥, at selv de vÃ¦rste mennesker kan blive figurer i en fortÃ¦lling. Det er et koncept med potentiale, men Murphy og Brennan bruger det som endnu en symbolsk leg i et rodet univers, der i forvejen har symbolik til overflod. I stedet for at bevare fokus pÃ¥ Ed Gein bliver Koch et pÃ¥skud for endnu en kunstfÃ¦rdig drÃ¸mmesekvens. NÃ¥r serien mod slutningen prÃ¦senterer sin parade af seriemordere â€“ fra Ed Kemper til Ted Bundy â€“ som alle pÃ¥ Ã©n eller anden mÃ¥de Â»stod pÃ¥ skuldreneÂ« af Gein, tipper den endegyldigt over. Billedmontagen er designet som en advarsel, men fÃ¸les som en hyldest. Det, der skulle vÃ¦re et moralsk punktum, bliver i stedet en kavalkade af ondskab i slowmotion, iscenesat som en trailer for menneskeligt forfald. Serien spÃ¸rger os, om vi ikke ogsÃ¥ er monstre, fordi vi ser med. Men spÃ¸rgsmÃ¥let falder fladt til jorden, nÃ¥r selve formen er bygget pÃ¥ det blik, den forsÃ¸ger at kritisere. Sponsoreret indhold Man kan ikke undgÃ¥ at fÃ¥ tanken undervejs: Er det her seriÃ¸st en hyldest til en bestialsk morder? Serien peger pÃ¥ os som de egentlige monstre, men har gjort Gein til noget nÃ¦r en kunstner. NÃ¥r den lader ham tale med Ilse Koch, og nÃ¥r den lader ham drÃ¸mme i poetiske billeder, bliver det ikke et portrÃ¦t af vanvid. Det bliver en Ã¦stetisk romantisering af grusomhed. Havde vi haft de filmiske mestervÃ¦rker uden Ed Gein, og ville vi gerne vÃ¦re dem foruden, virker Murphy & co. til at spÃ¸rge. Et spÃ¸rgsmÃ¥l sÃ¥ frÃ¦kt, at det ikke engang fortjener et svar. Skuespillet er stÃ¦rkt, og de kolde billedskud frustrerende forfÃ¸rende. Og til tider bliver man revet med af den sÃ¸rgelige fortÃ¦lling og Ã¦stetikken, sÃ¥ man nÃ¦sten glemmer sin irritation over forherligelsen. Serien vil vÃ¦re afsige dom og komme med sin bekendelse, men den ender med at vÃ¦re sit eget nedslÃ¥ende svar pÃ¥ det kritiske spÃ¸rgsmÃ¥l, den stiller â€“ snarere end blot at undersÃ¸ge sit monster. Kort sagt:â€™Monster: The Ed Gein Storyâ€™ er visuelt imponerende, og Charlie Hunnams kontrastfyldte portrÃ¦t af Ed Gein er svÃ¦rt medrivende, men serien drukner i et virvar af sidehistorier og kunstfÃ¦rdige referencer til horrorhistorien. Det, der kunne have vÃ¦ret et psykologisk studie af ensomhed og ondskab, ender som en Ã¦stetisk romantisering af en morder. â€™Monster: The Ed Gein Storyâ€™ sÃ¦son 3. Serie. Serieskabere: Ryan Murphy & Ian Brennan. Medvirkende: Charlie Hunnam, Laurie Metcalf, Suzanna Son, Tom Hollander, Vicky Krieps, Olivia Williams, Lesley Manville, Joey Pollari, Addison Rae. Spilletid: 8 episoder Ã¡ cirka 50 minutters varighed. Premiere: Kan ses pÃ¥ Netflix. Sponsoreret indhold

title: Dwayne Johnson reagerer pÃ¥ karrierens vÃ¦rste Ã¥bningsweekend: Â»Denne film har Ã¦ndret mit livÂ«

body_text: 7. okt. 2025 Af Morten KildebÃ¦k Dwayne Johnson reagerer pÃ¥ karrierens vÃ¦rste Ã¥bningsweekend: Â»Denne film har Ã¦ndret mit livÂ« 'The Smashing Machine'. title: Det vÃ¦rste ved Taylor Swifts nye disstrack er, at det ikke engang er underholdende
author: Rasmus Weirup
body_text: 7. okt. 2025 Af Rasmus Weirup Det vÃ¦rste ved Taylor Swifts nye disstrack er, at det ikke engang er underholdende Det er svÃ¦rt ikke at ligne en mobber, nÃ¥r man selv er urÃ¸rlig. Taylor Swift. (Foto: Universal) KOMMENTAR. Da Taylor Swift for to Ã¥r siden udgav sin genindspillede udgave af 2010-albummet â€™Speak Nowâ€™, var der sÃ¦rligt Ã©n ting, der vakte opsigt. Â»Sheâ€™s better known for the things that she does on the mattressÂ«, en kontroversiel linje fra det aggressive smÃ¦deskrift â€™Better than Revengeâ€™, var blevet skrevet ud af sangen. Sponsoreret indhold I stedet lÃ¸d det: Â»He was a moth to the flame / She was holding the matchesÂ«. En linje, der muligvis mangler en smule af originalens sydende bitterhed, men ikke desto mindre lÃ¦gger vÃ¦sentligt mindre op til anklager om slut shaming. FÃ¥ Ã¥r forinden markerede Swift afslutningen pÃ¥ en lang beef med Katy Perry â€“ noget med nogen, der havde hyret den andens dansere â€“ i videoen til positivitetshymnen â€™You Need to Calm Downâ€™, hvor de to popstjerner krammede hinanden klÃ¦dt ud som en burger og en bakke pomfritter. En metafor for deres stÃ¦rke kompatibilitet, forstod man. Tiden, hvor kvindelige popstjerner var i krig med hinanden, var slut. Om det er symptomatisk for en generel Ã¦ndring i tidsÃ¥nden er mÃ¥ske for meget at konkludere, men nÃ¥r man lytter til â€™Actually Romanticâ€™ â€“ Swifts bemÃ¦rkelsesvÃ¦rdigt usÃ¸sterlige disstrack fra â€˜The Life of a Showgirlâ€™ â€“ er det svÃ¦rt at tro pÃ¥, at det er en samme kunstner, vi har med at gÃ¸re. Sponsoreret indhold PÃ¥ â€™Actually Romanticâ€™ er de feministiske flÃ¸jlshandsker flÃ¥et af, og hÃ¦vngerrigheden er tilbage. SvÃ¦rt ikke at ligne en mobber â€™Actually Romanticâ€™ er efter alt at dÃ¸mme Swifts respons til Charli XCXâ€™s â€™Sympathy Is a Knifeâ€™ â€“ et uhyre menneskeligt bekendelsesskrift om at blive ramt af overvÃ¦ldende mindrevÃ¦rdskomplekser og sygelig jalousi, nÃ¥r man er i rum med verdens uden sammenligning stÃ¸rste popstjerne â€“ og om at skamme sig over fÃ¸lelser, man godt ved er irrationelle. â€™Actually Romanticâ€™, hvor Swift kalder Charli et cokehoved og en lille skÃ¸dehund, er mindre fÃ¸lelsesmÃ¦ssigt kompleks. Sangen bygger pÃ¥ en psykologiske klichÃ©, der ofte reserveres til bÃ¸rnehavedrenge, der hiver pigerne i rottehalerne: Â»Itâ€™s actually sweet / All the time youâ€™ve spent on meÂ«. Den man tugter, elsker man. Ud fra alle parametre er â€™Actually Romanticâ€™ en besynderlig respons fra Swift. For det fÃ¸rste fordi sangen tyder pÃ¥, at Swift â€“ der pÃ¥ sit forrige album iscenesatte sig selv som en tortured poet og har sammenlignet sig selv med en engelsklÃ¦rer â€“ simpelthen mangler lÃ¦sefÃ¦rdigheder og ikke er i stand til at afkode budskabet i â€™Sympathy Is a Knifeâ€™. Sponsoreret indhold Men ogsÃ¥ fordi sangen sÃ¥ Ã¥benlyst ikke harmonerer med den salvelsesfulde moralisering i andre sange pÃ¥ â€™The Life of a Showgirlâ€™. Â»Everybodyâ€™s so punk on the internet / Everyoneâ€™s unbothered â€™til theyâ€™re not / Every jokeâ€™s just trolling and memes / Sad as it seems, apathy is hot / Everybodyâ€™s cutthroat in the comments / Every single hot take is cold as iceÂ«, lyder det for eksempel i den gammelkloge â€™Eldest Daughterâ€™, inden hun i omkvÃ¦det konkluderer: Â»Iâ€™m not a bad bitch / And this isnâ€™t savageÂ«. Okay, sÃ¥. Mest af alt kan det dog undre, at PR-eksperten Taylor Swift â€“ popmusikkens mest virtuose dirigent af den offentlige samtale â€“ stadig er til falds for sange, som helt Ã¥benlyst fÃ¥r hende selv til at fremstÃ¥ tarvelig. Â»Someday, Iâ€™ll be big enough so you canâ€™t hit meÂ«, profeterede hun pÃ¥ 2010-disstracket â€™Meanâ€™. Det fik hun uden tvivl ret i. Der er praktisk talt ikke et eneste menneske pÃ¥ jorden, Swift kan sparke ud efter uden samtidig at sparke nedad. Sponsoreret indhold Â»Iâ€™m immortal now, baby dollsÂ«, synger hun pÃ¥ titelsangen fra â€˜The Life of a Showgirlâ€™. Selv hvis Charli oprigtigt har sÃ¥ret Swift, er det svÃ¦rt ikke at ligne en mobber, nÃ¥r man selv er urÃ¸rlig. Intet glimt i Ã¸jet Det er egentlig ikke, fordi jeg mener, at man kan eller bÃ¸r krÃ¦ve, at popstjerner skal fremstÃ¥ sympatiske (eller vÃ¦re konsekvente i forhold til det, de signalerer gennem deres sange). Ligesom Swift kan jeg godt lide mine popstjerner Â»cloaked in Gucci and in scandalÂ«. Min kÃ¦rlighed til popmusik udspringer fra en dyrkelse af musikhistoriens store, uforsonlige personligheder fra Barbra Streisand til Madonna. Intrigante divaer med rablende storhedsvanvid, der ikke er bange for slÃ¥ fra sig. De bedste, mest dragende stjerner er i familie med drag queens, nÃ¥r det kommer til at levere en god fornÃ¦rmelse sÃ¥ eftertrykkeligt, at den bidder sig fast som en flÃ¥t. Sponsoreret indhold Â»Den kjole gÃ¸r intet godt for hendeÂ«, har jeg hÃ¸rt en drag queen sige om en rival, der lige var ankommet til festen â€“ alt for hÃ¸jt og med sÃ¥dan en nÃ¥deslÃ¸s vÃ¦mmelse, at jeg fik gÃ¥sehud. Jeg elsker det. Jeg lever for Aretha Franklins knastÃ¸rre Â»smukke kjolerÂ«, da hun bliver spurgt til, hvad hun mener om Taylor Swift. Og Mariah Careys ikoniske Â»I donâ€™t know herÂ«, da emnet falder pÃ¥ Jennifer Lopez. Men den slags krÃ¦ver en varme, et glimt i Ã¸jet, en form for teatralsk ekspressivitet, en snert af humoristisk sans, en generÃ¸s bevidsthed om, at lysten til hÃ¦vn ikke mÃ¥ veje tungere end publikums krav pÃ¥ at blive underholdt, noget ubestemmeligt, vi kunne kalde camp. Alt sammen ting, â€˜Actually Romanticâ€™ desperat mangler. â€˜The Life of a Showgirlâ€™ er ude nu. Sponsoreret indhold

title: PlayStation Plus Extra Reportedly Gets Silent Hill 2 Remake Later This Month
body_text: Related reads:Silent Hill 2 Remake Developer Bloober Signs Deal for Another Game for Konami â€” Could It Be More Silent Hill? Last year's celebrated Silent Hill 2 Remake will join the PlayStation Plus Extra catalogue later this month, it's been reported.Via Dealabs, reliable tipster Billbil-kun has stated that the Silent Hill 2 Remake will become available via PlayStation Plus Extra on October 21.The game would be an extra treat â€” well timed for the spooky season â€” on top of the three monthly games currently on offer to all PlayStation Plus subscribers: Alan Wake 2, Goat Simulator 3 and Cocoon.Silent Hill 2 Remake's apparent arrival on PlayStation Plus Extra would come just after the game's first anniversary (it launched for PC and PS5 in October 2024), and amid a swirl of rumors surrounding new content for the game, including its unannounced but fan-anticipated Born from a Wish DLC. Indeed, survival horror leaker Dusk Golem has suggested Silent Hill 2 Remake will soon be updated with PS5 Pro support at the same time as the DLC's launch â€” which also now sounds like it could potentially be timed alongside its PlayStation Plus arrival. For the uninitiated, Born from a Wish is a side-story added to the original Silent Hill 2 which stars Maria as its playable character. Eagle-eyed fans have spotted hints to the story's content within the base game, though publisher Konami has so far kept schtum on the DLC actually existing.To date, Silent Hill 2 Remake remains a PlayStation console exclusive. So far, there's been no word of when it might launch on other platforms, such as Xbox Series X/S or even Nintendo Switch 2. Here's hoping we hear more soon.IGN's Silent Hill 2 Remake review returned an 8/10 score, and dubbed it "a welcome modernisation of a survival horror masterpiece. It smoothly polishes down the rough edges of the original gameâ€™s combat while taking a piece of heavy grit sandpaper to scuff up every rust and mold-covered surface of its nightmarish environments, successfully making them appear far more abrasive and menacing to explore."Tom Phillips is IGN's News Editor. You can reach Tom at tom_phillips@ign.com or find him on Bluesky @tomphillipseg.bsky.social Related reads:Silent Hill 2 Remake Is Just $30 at Walmart

title: Battlefield 6 Leaks Seem Unstoppable as Players Report Receiving Copies Days Before Launch
body_text: Related reads:Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 Beta Extended by 24 Hours, Ends Just a Day Before the Battlefield 6 Release Date Battlefield 6 has suffered numerous leaks throughout 2025, and now, just three days before launch, the game itself may have leaked its way into the publicâ€™s hands, too.Reddit users grecea_vlad and SS-Enter-Thighs shared they had recently managed to secure early copies, posting images of what seem to be Phantom Edition versions of the game that have been unintentionally released days before Battlefield 6â€™s October 10 release date.It is finally in my hands byu/grecea_vlad inBattlefieldBox art highlighted in both posts features labels from the European video game ratings board, PEGI, suggesting both copies were sold by European retailers. Itâ€™s unclear which store(s) could be responsible for the alleged leak or how pre-release copies of Battlefield 6 could have slipped through the cracks and into the fansâ€™ hands. Of course, that may not be a concern for the two â€“ or maybe even more â€“ Battlefield 6 fans who now have the game in hand days before everyone else.EA announced global release times for Battlefield 6 yesterday, confirming there would be no early access for players who pre-ordered certain versions of the game. Despite outlining firm launch times, both Reddit users say they are able to access the campaign mode and even some online features, including online play with bots, as grecea_vlad says servers are already online.Itâ€™s unclear which features these supposed early Battlefield 6 adopters have access to, so for everyone else still waiting for official launch, itâ€™s probably best to be wary of spoilers for the next few days, just in case.Meanwhile, EA and the four-company team that makes up Battlefield Studios recently previewed some of the changes set to be introduced with the Battlefield 6 day one patch. Itâ€™s a tease for this Fridayâ€™s patch that also came with an update regarding the debate between Closed and Open Weapons, as the developers insisted that â€œthe vast majority of playersâ€ prefer the latter.We spoke to the Battlefield team at Ripple Effect to learn more about how BF Studios has prepped for the launch of Battlefield 6 last month. Along with a closer look at how the experience has been molded throughout the last few years, our chat yielded new information about how EA and BF Studios approached leaks during development.Michael Cripe is a freelance writer with IGN. He's best known for his work at sites like The Pitch, The Escapist, and OnlySP. Be sure to give him a follow on Bluesky (@mikecripe.bsky.social) and Twitter (@MikeCripe). Related reads:Battlefield 6 Global Release Times Confirmed

title: Battlefield 6 Day One Patch Includes Changes to Movement, Weapon Recoil, Rush, and More
body_text: Related reads:Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 Beta Extended by 24 Hours, Ends Just a Day Before the Battlefield 6 Release Date EA and Battlefield Studios have previewed some of the gameplay tweaks and balance changes coming with the Battlefield 6 day one patch.Information about the first patch for this weekâ€™s long-awaited back-to-basics Battlefield game was outlined in a post on its official website today. It comes with a breakdown from the team explaining how their pre-release Battlefield Labs and beta tests helped them prepare for launch, with the first Battlefield 6 patch set to provide an even more stable foundation.Those who played the Battlefield 6 open beta in August will notice several fundamental changes to how the DICE, Criterion, Ripple Effect, and Motive-developed game feels after its day one patch is downloaded. Todayâ€™s first look at the Battlefield 6 launch update is only a taste of what's to come, with full patch notes for the more than 200 changes set to arrive later this week.Topping the list are tweaks the BF Studios team says will make movement feel more responsive, including fixes for â€œseveral movement issuesâ€ and changes to pacing. Weapon attachments should also display correctly across the Battlefield 6 experience, with the day one patch also promising rebalanced automatic weapons that make long-range gunplay more rewarding for tap firing and burst control.Beta players will also be happy to hear Rush and Breakthrough have been reworked to improve balance between both the attacking and defending teams. Gadgets in Battlefield 6 will also be changed for the day one patch. The MBT-LAW, for example, is now set as the default Engineer launcher, while the MAS 148 now behaves more realistically, and Deploy Beacons have been updated to limit one spawn per player.While the Battlefield 6 day one patch also promises updated UI and HUD elements, cleaner audio, improved network stability, and more, todayâ€™s post also comes with an update on one of the most hotly contested topics in the community: Open vs. Closed Weapons. Closed locks guns to specific classes, while Open allows each class to utilize a variety of different weapon types. Despite waves of fans hoping to see the BF Studios team lean on Closed classes for Battlefield 6, the team insisted in todayâ€™s post that Open classes were preferred by â€œthe vast majority of players.â€â€œLastly, another key insight from the Open Beta was that the vast majority of players, after trying both playlist types, chose to stick with Open Weapons,â€ BF Studios says. â€œThis reinforces our belief that Open Weapons is the right path forward for Battlefield 6. At the same time, we recognize that some players prefer the Closed Weapons experience. To support them, official Closed Weapons playlists will be available at launch.â€œAdditionally, Closed Weapons mutators will remain part of the Portal toolset, so players can create and share their own custom experiences.â€Battlefield 6 has a release date of October 10 for PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X and S. Check out the Battlefield 6 global release times if you want to know when you'll be able to play in your timezone. Season 1, meanwhile, kicks off October 28 and will deliver additional maps, guns, vehicles, and more, with additional updates planned for November 18 and December 9.Based on our time with the Battlefield 6 beta, weâ€™ve got a BF6 Beginnerâ€™s Guide and Tips, plus the best Battlefield 6 Loadouts and how to use the Range Finder, deploy the Bipod, and how to turn off Haptic Feedback in Battlefield 6.Finally, you can see everything we know about the Battlefield 6 day one patch below.Battlefield 6 Day One Patch Notes Preview:The following gameplay updates will be included in our launch day patch, with over 200 changes focused on bug fixes, balance improvements, and polish for release. Stay tuned for the full launch day update notes closer to launch!PlayerYouâ€™ll notice that movement feels more responsive, with changes made to pacing and with several movement issues addressed to keep gameplay smooth and balanced.WeaponsRecoil has been rebalanced on automatic weapons, making long-range gunplay more characteristic, rewarding tap firing and burst control.Numerous weapon attachments have been fixed so they now display correctly in menus and in-game.GadgetsThe LTLM II (Laser Designator) has been refined with smoother deploy animations, updated visuals, and several fixes for better feel when used.The MBT-LAW is now the default Engineer launcher, with a more accurate trajectory, improved guidance, and clearer sights.The MAS 148 Glaive is enhanced with more realistic missile path, improved zoom and lock-on, sharper scope visuals, and more reliable vehicle damage.Deploy Beacons are now limited to one spawn per player (four per squad total), helping maintain balance and prevent overuse.Maps and ModesRush and Breakthrough layouts have been revised for better balance between attackers and defenders.Operation Firestorm has been updated with improved vaulting, lightning, and performance, while Siege of Cairo spawn killing and Out of Bounds issues have been addressed.UI & HUDUI and HUD elements are clearer, with updated overlays, animated pings, new minimap options, and smoother loadout and deploy navigation.SettingsSettings and controls have expanded with new options like VO volume sliders, sprint bob reduction, and a camera roll toggle for accessibility, plus refinements across platforms.AudioAudio has been cleaned up so pings are easier to hear, weapons and vehicles sound sharper, and missing delayed effects wonâ€™t get in the way of your awareness.NetworkNetcode improvements reduce desync, make time-to-death feel fairer, and address cases of invisible damage.Michael Cripe is a freelance writer with IGN. He's best known for his work at sites like The Pitch, The Escapist, and OnlySP. Be sure to give him a follow on Bluesky (@mikecripe.bsky.social) and Twitter (@MikeCripe). Related reads:Battlefield 6 Global Release Times Confirmed

title: Predator: Badlands - Official Final Trailer
body_text: 02:53 Inside the Predator: Badlands Experience at Comic-Con | Comic Con 2025

title: 12 Things We Learned Visiting the Set of Predator: Badlands
body_text: Related reads:Predator: Badlands Is Confirmed PG-13 Rather Than R-Rated, and Fans of the Famously Violent Franchise Certainly Have Opinions About That In the middle of 2024, IGN was invited to the southern suburban fringe of Auckland in New Zealand where, in several giant sound stages nestled amidst soccer fields and service stations, director Dan Trachtenberg and his team were busy crafting the out-of-this-world adventure Predator: Badlands. We spent a day wandering through the damaged hull of a crashed Yautja spaceship, got up close and personal with the hi-tech exterior of a Weyland-Yutani research base, and stared up at a towering replica of a redwood forest canopy to be used for a spectacular stunt sequence.We also got to spend time with the cast and crew, including producer Ben Rosenblatt who laid out his and Trachtenbergâ€™s vision for a predator movie unlike any that has come before in the series. â€œThis all takes place way in the future after everything that we know from the universe of Alien and Weyland-Yutani and Predator and Alien vs. Predator; all that stuff,â€ explained Rosenblatt. â€œThis is the farthest out [the series has] gone. [And for] the tone of the movie we're trying to strike a balance between all the cool badass stuff that you'd expect out of a Predator film â€“ lots of great action, lots of serious moments, and the badass stuff â€“ but also we want it to be like an adventure film [where] we actually connect with the characters. So that's kind of the balance we're taking.â€Hereâ€™s everything we learned visiting the set of Predator: Badlands. 1. Predator: Badlands is Turning the Hunter into the Hunted Predator: Badlandsâ€™ most radical change right off the bat is that it casts a young predator named Dek as the hero of the story (played by Dimitrius Schuster-Koloamatangi). Although these â€œugly motherf**kersâ€ have served as intimidating antagonists ever since Arnieâ€™s special forces unit was dropped into a meat grinder in the 1987 original, Predator: Badlands asks audiences to sympathise with one of these mandible-mouthed monsters for the very first time.â€œOur story begins on Yautja Prime with this predator and his immediate family and, through a series of both exciting and tragic events, he's set off on a journey on a foreign planet [Genna] and that's where most of the film is taking place,â€ explained Rosenblatt.Director Dan Trachtenberg, who also helmed 2022â€™s superb albeit disappointingly straight-to-streaming Predator prequel Prey, is confident that fans will have no problem warming to Dek despite being conditioned to view previous predators as some sort of unstoppable, intergalactic Jason Vorheesâ€™ in every other Predator film.Predator: Badlands asks audiences to sympathise with one of these mandible-mouthed monsters for the very first time.â€œI've just always had a deep affection for underdog stories,â€ said Trachtenberg. â€œPrey was certainly that and I think Dekâ€™s story is still that of an underdog. Heâ€™s involved in a very traumatic event in the beginning of the movie that he's taking this whole adventure to deal with. So, from the jump you are thrust into a really high intensity, physical and emotional situation with him that I think will really put you in his shoes.â€Schuster-Koloamatangi, appearing in his first major Hollywood role, agrees that Predator: Badlands is set to give fans something that theyâ€™ve never experienced before.â€œIt's cool to be able to follow one of the predators that everyone is so scared of and then kind of have a deeper look into their culture, into their background, what makes them them, and kind of understand why it is they're travelling around everywhere killing everybody,â€ said Schuster-Koloamatangi.2. Itâ€™s Not a Sequel to PreyDespite the fact that the dynamic duo behind Predator: Badlands, director Dan Trachtenberg and producer Ben Rosenblatt, is the same core production team that was behind 2022â€™s excellent Predator prequel, Prey, this new movie is not to be considered as a Prey 2. But that doesnâ€™t mean that Trachtenberg and Rosenblatt donâ€™t have hopes for a Prey 2 in the future.â€œPrey is something we're very proud of, we love [it], we're happy other people loved it. It's not something we're abandoning,â€ said Rosenblatt. â€œWe could have done a Prey 2, we could have done a Prey where itâ€™s a different time period, but I think for us we were like how do we move things forward? [Prey] was something people hadnâ€™t done with the franchise before. In thinking about what to do next, Dan was really set on [coming up with] the kind of big swing that no oneâ€™s taken yet.â€3. Itâ€™s Not an Alien vs. Predator Movie Either, Although it Does Feature Weyland-YutaniA part of that big swing is to crossover the plot of Predator: Badlands with the Alien universe, by featuring synthetic soldiers and researchers dispatched to the planet Genna by the infamous xenomorph-weaponising Weyland-Yutani corporation. However, itâ€™s strictly synths in Predator: Badlands; there will be none of HR Gigerâ€™s chest-bursting creations along for the ride.â€œIt's not an Alien vs. Predator movie so there will not be a xenomorph,â€ confirmed Rosenblatt. â€œHopefully one day, but this is kind of us dipping our toe. The worlds coexist and this is kind of like bringing them together.â€â€œThe back story is that Weyland-Yutani has sent an all-synth mission onto this planet to pursue the very same beast for their own purposes,â€ explained Rosenblatt. â€œObviously, the Yautja are interested in honour-killing and proving themselves and Weyland-Yutani often has a different objective. So that is who [Dek] encounters along the way. He does not know that at first but that is what it ultimately becomes.â€Thatâ€™s not to say that there wonâ€™t be some Alien-centric easter eggs to be spotted in Predator: Badlands. During our set visit we were able to walk around the deck of a crashed predator spaceship, presumably belonging to either Dek or one of his family members, and we spied a trophy room adorned with what very much looked like xenomorph skullsâ€¦4. Elle Fanning Plays Two Synths, Thia and TessaDeath Stranding 2â€™s Elle Fanning plays the twin roles of Weyland-Yutani synthetics Thia and Tessa. The former is both literally and figuratively bonded with Dek over the course of the adventure, with the latter seemingly in hot pursuit of the plucky young predator and his legless passenger. But, given how far into the future Predator: Badlands is set, Fanning is imbuing these synths with far more humanity than what weâ€™ve come to expect from the likes of Ian Holmâ€™s Ash or Michael Fassbenderâ€™s David in previous instalments in the Alien franchise. â€œWhen you see David in Prometheus, thereâ€™s a quality to the acting that feels somewhat robotic,â€ said Rosenblatt. â€œWe are not playing that. Weâ€™re thinking of them as being the latest iteration [of synths] to the extent that they can feel, more so than anyone weâ€™ve seen so far.â€Thia and Tessa are research synths dispatched to the planet by Weyland-Yutani to harvest what they can from it, for typically nefarious Weyland-Yutani purposes, but Fanningâ€™s twins arenâ€™t the only synths in Predator: Badlands. The research mission is led by more militaristic androids, so presumably there will be quite a lot of predator-on-synth violence in store.5. The Predators Have Their Own Language NowIn previous films the predators have communicated using a combination of basic clicks and pitch-perfect Jesse Ventura impressions, but for Predator: Badlands the filmmakers have gone ahead and created a full language for the Yautja creatures. Thanks to the work of language expert Britton Watkins, the Yautja in Predator: Badlands actually speak to each other in full sentences (translated into subtitles for the audienceâ€™s benefit), and all of the markings on their weaponry and armour have actual meaning rather than simply serving an ornamental purpose. â€œWhat Britton did was, as much as possible, he took everything that had come before [in previous films] and said, â€˜Okay, let me try to synthesise this into a working language,â€™â€ explains Rosenblatt. â€œHeâ€™s developed the alphabet. Thereâ€™s a dictionary. [But] one of the biggest challenges for Britton in creating the language, was making sure that it fits what is anatomically possible with the Yautja face and mouth and that kind of thing. Like working the clicks into it and making something sort of guttural and not too much enunciation or tongue action.â€6. Predator: Badlands was Inspired by The Empire Strikes BackFor much of Predator: Badlands, Dek is saddled with Thiaâ€™s legless body in a backpack, after she just barely survives an attack from a native Genna monster called a Kalisk. From there the film becomes a road trip buddy movie of sorts, with the pair slowly forging a bond while also defying death in the face of Gennaâ€™s numerous threats. â€œI love the pairing. My pitch was that it was like Chewbacca and C-3PO: The Movie. Like the end of The Empire Strikes Back? I was tantalized by the fun of that,â€ said Trachtenberg.Trachtenberg namechecks Conan the Barbarian as being a key reference point when crafting Badlands' setting.Star Wars hasnâ€™t been the only significant influence on the film, however. Trachtenberg also namechecks Conan the Barbarian as being a key reference point when crafting Badlandsâ€™ setting, claiming â€œthereâ€™s something in the fabric of that world thatâ€™s fantasy but brutal, and pirate-y, thatâ€™s different than Lord of the Rings or Game of Thrones or Avatar.â€ Speaking of pirates, he also points to another â€™80s classic as providing a source of inspiration.â€œThe Goonies,â€ said Trachtenberg. â€œThere was almost more Goonies [influence] in the movie. Weâ€™ll see; thereâ€™s still time for there to be more Goonies in it.â€Will Dek be forced to perform a truffle shuffle to entertain the shattered synth strapped to his back? Maybe in the directorâ€™s cut.7. The Predator Faces Are Being Created Digitallyâ€¦While the monsterâ€™s face in the original Predator was a gurgling feat of practical VFX brilliance from master make-up effects artist Stan Winston, the predators in Badlands will be a combination of both practical and digital effects according to creature designer Alec Gillis. Gillis is a veteran of the VFX world, having worked on multiple entries in both the Alien and Predator series, along with Godzilla vs. Kong, It, Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom, and countless others. According to him, a blend of both worlds is essential to achieve the very best results.â€œWe'll base things as much as we can in reality, in physical pieces, and then we use the CGI to augment and to build the world and the universe that they inhabit,â€ explained Gillis. â€œBecause you can't make a modern movie without really beautiful digital effects. Sometimes the fans get a little like villagers carrying the torches saying, â€˜We hate CGI,â€™ and we're like, â€˜No, no, you only don't like the CGI that you're noticing.â€™ Every movie that you watch now, every shot is somehow touched digitally. Either through colour grading or compositing or fixes and so on.â€Gillis and his team did initially attempt to craft the predator faces with a combination of makeup and animatronics to reasonably good results, but in the end he decided to draft in the expertise of the animators at Weta Digital to provide more subtle facial expression via motion capture.â€œRight around the time we were doing the [physical test], we got to see Kingdom of the Planet of the Apes and it had such spectacular performances,â€ explained Gillis. â€œItâ€™s undeniable. As an artist, I have to stand up for my craft, but I also have to be able to look a director in the eye and say you have to use the right tool for the right application.â€8. â€¦ But There Are Still Plenty of Practical Effects and Shots On LocationThat said, Predator: Badlandsâ€™ production team has still gone to great lengths to rely on practical effects as much as possible, creating physical replicas of many of the creatures to feature in scenes rather than force its cast to engage with the old tennis-ball-on-a-stick trick. â€œYou see real creatures on set interacting with actors, and thatâ€™s always a great thing when acting is reacting,â€ said Gillis. â€œSo if you give someone something to play off, then you [get] a better result.â€The stunt team, led by coordinator Jacob Tomuri, also went to exhaustive lengths to allow Schuster-Koloamatangiâ€™s Dek to carry Fanningâ€™s Thia on his back in the most convincing manner possible, during the roughly 30 days of the filmâ€™s production that took place on location in New Zealandâ€™s Redwoods Forest.Predator: Badlands' production team has still gone to great lengths to rely on practical effects as much as possible.â€œWe had to build truss towers and span slack lines between trees,â€ explained Tomuri. â€œAnd we created a thing called a bosunâ€™s chair, which we put underneath Elleâ€™s hamstrings and attached it to a spreader so we could travel her along the slack line with a counterweight system. It took up 70% of Elleâ€™s weight so it would still look like there was weight in the backpack, but it meant that Demetrius could do all the running, sprinting, jumping, and navigating through the landscape.â€Schuster-Koloamatangi, a New Zealander, relished the opportunity to have the natural beauty of his home country featured so prominently in the film despite the fact the physical nature of his performance took a bit of a toll.â€œThe shoulders are a bit bigger now than they were before I started [filming],â€ joked Schuster-Koloamatangi. â€œBut the pain is a privilege, and being out in New Zealand was just unreal. Because there are so many things a sound stage canâ€™t replicate. Being outdoors just adds that little texture that the film needs. It feels real, because it was.â€9. It Features Some Pretty Creative Fight SequencesThe Predator series is no stranger to spectacular scraps, from the original filmâ€™s final showdown between Schwarzeneggerâ€™s Dutch and the man-hunting monster, to the showcase of advanced weaponry and acrobatics involved in the predatorâ€™s slaughter of the fur trappers in Prey. Predator: Badlands is set to add a number of iconic encounters of its own to that list, from a major battle between Dek and a hulking monster called a Kalisk, to a fight between Dek and his brother Kwei dangling from stalactites in a cave â€“ unofficially dubbed the â€œstalacfightâ€ by the production crew.â€œI read the script and I thought it was incredibly original,â€ said Tomuri, who previously collaborated on the stunt sequences for George Millerâ€™s Furiosa. â€œSome of the sequences I was like, I've never actually seen that, or heard of that in any action sequence before.â€One such sequence highlighted by Tomuri involves a fight between Thia and some rival synths, which doesnâ€™t sound all that interesting until you consider the fact that Thiaâ€™s upper and lower body have been separated and are acting independently.â€œThe legs and the torso work together â€“ like a buddy fight â€“ to beat these synths up,â€ explained Tomuri. â€œAnd I was like, I can't say I've ever seen this before in anything and then also, how the hell am I going to do that?â€Trachtenberg agrees that one of the goals with Predator: Badlands is to push the envelope when it comes to fight choreography. â€œ[Youâ€™re going] to see things that weâ€™ve never gotten to see the predator do, other than maybe in some comics and games,â€ says Trachtenberg. â€œWeâ€™ve never seen the predator hunt on an alien planet, or at least hunt non-humans on an alien planet. Or seen a predator take on synths. Heâ€™s up against things that are way more crazy than weâ€™ve ever seen a predator deal with before.â€10. The Predatorâ€™s Arsenal is a Combination of Advanced Weaponry and Makeshift ToolsThe Predator series is synonymous with serious killing tools, from Jesse Venturaâ€™s rainforest-razing â€˜Old Painlessâ€™ mini-gun to the razor-edged smart disc in Predator 2 that homed in on body heat and returned to its user like a boomerang. However, Predator: Badlands is evidently switching to more organically sourced death-dealers, at least as far as its hero is concerned.â€œThe Predators always have weapons and cool gadgets and [Dek] has got that stuff,â€ explained Gillis. â€œBut it is stripped away from him in the crash by the lifeforms that are on this planet. And so we had this idea that what if he kind of recreates his weaponry through the use of organic things [he finds]?â€Examples presented to us include a whip fashioned out of â€˜razor grassâ€™, as well as a gauntlet crafted out of a vulture-like alienâ€™s beak. Lastly there is â€˜Squirtâ€™, a snake-like creature that Dek repurposes as a replacement for the more traditional predator shoulder cannon, wrapping its tail around his arm and pulling it to trigger an attack.â€œ[Dek] finds this lifeform that he trains to sit on his shoulder, and it has the ability to spit two chemicals that become explosive and fiery when they combine in the air,â€ said Gillis, going on to explain that the inspiration came from the real world Bombardier Beetle, which when threatened ejects a noxious spray by combining hydroquinone and hydrogen peroxide. That said, New Zealand-based Weta Workshop has also come to the table with a big variety of high-tech weaponry, a lot of it wielded by the combat synths that Dek is forced to contend with. Wandering around the propmasterâ€™s store room on set reveals a number of modular weapons like handguns that can transform into rifles, a gauntlet shield to be wielded by Dekâ€™s brother Kwei, as well as classic predator weapons like the telescopic combistick that can be used as both a hand-to-hand weapon and thrown like a spear. Schuster-Koloamatangi has a clear favourite weapon to wield, though. â€œItâ€™s the plasma sword. I like how it looks. I donâ€™t like how heavy it is, but the sword is really cool. Itâ€™s a massive sword.â€11. Predator: Badlands Wonâ€™t be R-rated, But it Will Still be Very ViolentThere will be plenty of blood spilled in Predator: Badlands, just not the kind that tends to get censorship boards all hot and bothered. Although synthetics, predators, and various other alien monsters will be violently torn asunder, not a single human character will be harmed during Badlandsâ€™ runtime, which should mean that the film receives a rating less severe than the majority of its predecessors.â€œWe'll see where it ends up, but our hope for it is that it can be a PG-13 that feels like an R,â€ said Rosenblatt. â€œThat's kind of our hope. And really, what that's about is just being able to broaden out the audience for a movie like this.â€â€œWe don't have any humans in the movie and so we don't have any human red blood,â€ continued Rosenblatt. â€œSo we're hoping that's gonna play to our advantage. We're going to go as hard as we possibly can within those constraints, and we think we'll be able to do some pretty awesomely gruesome stuff. But in colours other than red.â€Get ready for some milky synthetic goop and glowing green predator blood to fill the screen by the bucketload.12. Badlands is Aiming to be the Terminator 2 of the Predator SeriesTerminator 2: Judgement Day is one of the greatest action movies of all time, but tonally itâ€™s noticeably different to its predecessor, which was constructed more like a sci-fi slasher movie. Trachtenberg hopes that Predator: Badlands will stand apart from previous Predator films in a similar fashion.â€œ[The difference] for me is like, I never thought my mom should see The Terminator, but I did think she should see Terminator 2: Judgement Day,â€ explained Trachtenberg.â€œTerminator 2 is thematically oriented to be about parents and children, while also still badass and awesome. So it felt like a way to get my mom to watch a cool action movie [because] it had this whole other engine to it. It was really story focussed. So I really felt heartened that there is a way to continue doing these movies that can have a warmth at the centre but also still be incredibly ferocious and action-oriented and all the things that you'd expect from the Predator franchise.â€Will Predator: Badlands please both existing fans and newcomers alike? Will Dek evolve from runt of the litter to badarse hunter-killer? Will it setup the next instalment in the Alien vs. Predator series? Weâ€™ll get the answers to all of these questions and more, when Predator: Badlands arrives in theaters on November 7th, 2025. Tristan Ogilvie is a senior video editor at IGNâ€™s Sydney office. He travelled to the set of Predator: Badlands as a guest of Disney. Related reads:Predator: Badlands Director Confirms 'Thereâ€™s No Xenomorph in This Movie,' So the Aliens vs. Predator Rematch Is Going to Have to Wait
